label: Science & Mathematics
sentence:
Title: Oxalic acid's comp. is 26.7%C,2.2%H,71.1%O. its molecular weight is 90amu. What is its molecular formula?
Question: Oxalic acid is a toxic substance used by laundries to remove rust stains.  Its composition is 26.7% C, 2.2% H, and 71.1% O (by mass), and its molecular weight is 90amu.  What is its molecular formula?
Answer: Call it (CxHyOz)
Mass of C = 12x
Mass of H = 2y
Mass of O = 16z
-----------------------
Its molecular weight M = 12x + 2y + 16z = 90

Percentage of C: (12x / M) *100% = 26.7% <-> 12x = 90 * 26.7 / 100 <-> 12x = 24 <-> x = 2

You can do the same with H and O to find y = 2 and z = 4.

The formula is, hence, C2H2O4.

Question: In the documentary "Touching the Void", an atheist mountain climber with a broken leg is dropped 50 feet into a chasm during a blinding snowstorm on a remote peak. Smug Christians always say that atheists immediately turn to God at the first sign of adversity, but this climber found his atheist beliefs were stronger than ever. In fact, he argues that had he been a believer, he would have accepted events as "God's will", and just made his peace and waited either for a miracle rescue, or to die and join God in heaven. Instead, BECAUSE he was an atheist, he lowered himself further into the pitch black crevice. He dragged his broken leg behind him for days, without water, climbing over boulders, etc., and finally made it back to camp. Ironically, the non-atheist at the camp heard him crying for help, thought he was a ghost, and refused to leave the tent to help. Title: 'c' in e=mc^2?
Question: Why is the speed of light in Einstein's famous equation?
Answer: Einstein believed that the velocity of light was a constant, unchanged since the big bang. He was probably wrong about that, see articles on dark energy to learn why. Since Energy is expressed in joules which is a measure of work - moving one newton of mass one meter-, a measurement in meters per second was needed for the energy equation to solve with the proper units. Einstein believed that the square of the speed of light would account for the most extreme accleration possible and therefore would produce the highest theoretical yield of energy. At least that's what a lot of scientists think Einstein thought. Not a lot of people have had the capacity to think like Einstein so we are all just guessing from his speeches, writings, and calculations what he really thought.

Question: If a recepie asks for 1 cup of converted rice, does that mean 1 cup cooked rice?
Answer: Converted rice is beige. It tastes a lot like white rice, but it has more nutrients.
http://www.foodsubs.com/Rice.html#converted
Converted rice: Converted rice has been soaked and steamed under pressure before milling, which forces some of the nutrients into the remaining portion of the grain so that they are not completely lost in the processing. Enriched parboiled rice is similar to regular enriched rice in terms of thiamin, niacin, and iron, but it has more potassium, folate (folic acid), riboflavin, and phosphorous, though not as much as brown rice. Converted rice takes a little longer to cook than regular rice, but the grains will be very fluffy and separate after they have been cooked. 
http://www.wholehealthmd.com/refshelf/foods_view/1,1523,75,00.html

label: Health
sentence:
Title: If You eat 800 calories a day will you lose weight?
Question: Hey! I'm really worried about one of my friends she is saying she is fat when she is not. I insist on telling her she is fine the way she is and is beautiful but she thinks she is huge. She's told me she is on this diet that she only eats 800 calories a day. Is this true? is this healthy? will she lose weight? I don't want her to get hurt but she won't listen to me what can I do to help her!!!!!!
Answer: Yes, she will lose weight. And muscle tissue and brain functionality,strength and endurance. She is dangerously below what she needs in a day (usually 1200-1600 calories are recommended for those who are extremely overweight). Sounds like she may need to seek counseling because if she sees something different than what really exists when she looks in the mirror, then her mind's eye needs to be reprogrammed. These are often beginning signs of anorexia and bulimia. Encourage her to talk to a counselor. She is in danger of harming herself by doing these things. This is not the time to keep your thoughts to yourself. If necessary, ask for help from a trusted adult to intervene. She may get mad at you, but it's worth it to save her life. Be encouraged.

Wash it with a mild bleach and water solution, then put an ice pack on it for 10-15 minutes. That should get rid of the swelling and redness. Then you need to treat it with an insecticide. I suggest RAID ant and roach spray. But you could try malathion or DDT.

Hope it helps.

Sincerely,
Terry

label: Education & Reference
sentence:
Question: How do wirlpools start in the ocean?
Answer: As the water starts to circle, it is thrown to the outside, due to centrifugal force (to be more accurate, the force that it experiences is centripetal force=(mv^2)/r since centrifugal force is a so-called fictitious force). As it's thrown outside, it starts to move faster (when things move in a circle, the things that are nearer the outside move faster than things near the center; you can see this if you have a "old-fashioned" record player by putting two coins on it, one near the center and one near the outer edge and trace how long it takes them to complete the lengths of their paths). So the circling water near the outer rim is moving very fast and experiences bigger forces (since the force is proportional to velocity). But the water near the middle is moving slower because it's being dragged along the bottom and so ends up slowing down much more. Since the water near the bottom is moving so slowly, it exhibits a much lower centrifugal force and so there is little to no centrifugal force near the bottom (or middle). This is why you have a whirlpool (vortex): the water near the top is pushed out more (since there's higher centrifugal force there) and the water near the bottom is hardly pushed outward at all (since there's lower centrifugal force near the bottom to push it out).

label: Science & Mathematics
sentence:
Title: whats the deal with the male sea horse giing birth to his young?
Question: can you also give me an evolutionary aspect?  Do any other animals behave that way?
Answer: They only hold the eggs in a special sac, until they hatch.  (I think seahorses are egglayers.)  Once the young seahorses are ready to lead independent lives, he dumps them out of the sac.

I think it is comparable to the way male emus incubate the eggs of their partners.  Male emus (an Australian bird, similar to the ostrich and rhea) also cares for the young; they follow him, for a while after hatching.

See?  The females lay eggs / give birth, really.  These males just participate in care of their offspring.  Their babies are thus more likely to grow up and have offspring; the trait has selective advantages.

In general, females put a lot more into young than males do.  In some species, the way "female" is distinguished from "male" is by comparing the size of their gametes.  Note how sperm are smaller than ova, for example.  In many cases, the female adds a huge load of nutrients to the young, too; the yolk + / or white of the egg, the placental nutrition of the foetus, the milk of mammals...  It all weakens the females, in cases where nutrients are limiting (which is the normal situation, "in the wild".

In cases where males take on the bulk of after - care, it just evens the load a bit, really.  It lets the females get back to replenishing their body nutrients, to get ready for the next brood.... probably sired by the same male.  (He wins again.)

Question: what are the best penny stocks to watch and buy?
Answer: They're all good to watch. Not many worth buying, unless you like being manipulated.

Anyone with a million dollars or so can pump and dump these stocks and send their prices soaring, so that you get in, then plunging, so that you lose everything very fast. 

Or the average guy, you for example, can start a new company building furniture. It's decent stuff and you have it built in the Caymans so your cost is cheap and you make money. Take the company public and issue stock with an IPO. 

When the stock soars on the IPO, sell your shares and start a subsidiary, and put all your money into that new company making T-shirts. Of course, the furniture company's stock fell considerably, because you took all of the cash out. 

When you make money on T-shirts, go public, and when the IPO soars, sell your shares, and buy back the furniture stock at depressed levels. Of course, the T-shirt stock goes down the tubes, because you pulled the cash out, but hey, you're making a killing onthe stock.

This is legal manipulation. You've been warned. Penny stocks are very risky for a reason, or lots of reasons. Buy something with known value, that's been around awhile, and will continue to be around. So what if you can't buy as many shares? You can still double your money, and reduce your risk in half, by investing in the future of a stable company not ran or manipulated by shysters.

label: Education & Reference
sentence:
Question: Which is the oldest university in the world?
Answer: Al-Azhar University in Cairo, Egypt, is generally considered to be the oldest university in the world.* It was founded roughly the same time as the city of Cairo, in 969 AD. The first lecture was delivered in 975 AD. 
Like many centers of learning, Al-Azhar University was originally intended as a place of worship and religious instruction. The mosque at Al-Azhar is one of the most famous in the Muslim world, and is still considered the seat of Sunni Islamic study. 

The university pioneered systems of advanced academic instruction with its hierarchy of regular instructors and visiting professors. Its history follows the turbulent rise of the Islamic Empire, replete with political revolutions and competing religious philosophies. While Al-Azhar University has a storied history of religious instruction, it also boasts a robust secular curriculum, offering advanced degrees in engineering and medicine. 

As with all matters medieval, historical facts and figures are up to academic interpretation. Qarawiyyin Mosque in Fez, Morroco, has also laid claim to the title of oldest university in the world. 

Europe's oldest university was founded in 1088 in the northern Italian city of Bologna. The United States's oldest university, Harvard, opened in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in 1636, not long after the first English colonists arrived in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. 



*Nalanda University and Takshashila University, both ancient schools located in India, predate Al-Azhar University.

Title: Question about running?
Question: I am somewhat confused by this.  Okay, I worked out every week at least 3-4 times a week for a straight hour, and I would walk uphill at the highest incline at 4.3 miles an hr on the treadmill.  This went well, I burned 700 something cals an hour and combined with eating healthy, I managed to get from 130 in July to like 112 or so in early Nov.  Now I realized that my heart rate was NOT high at all- it was barely more than a resting rate! So I started running in the beginning of Nov (this month) and since then (Its been what, three weeks?) I have noticed MAJOR changes in my body.  I am suddenly a LOT slimmer, and have all this extra skin around my stomach from where I obviously just lost fat.  WHY?  Why so quick? Does it have to do with the heart rate? Its weird because I am burning less calories now- I run on the treadmill at a good steady pace of 5.6-6.5 miles an hour for about 30-40 min 5 times a week. But why did these physical changes just start showing up? My diet is good....
Answer: the calorie count on the machine may not be accurate.....if your heart rate is higher, you are likely burning more calories

also, you may have built up some muscle, which takes a little time......if this is the case, you should be burning more calories all day and night, and this will definitely speed up weight loss......

also, since you have less weight to lose, any loss will be a lot more obvious.....you may just lose a couple of pounds, and notice a big change, where before you wouldn't have noticed any just from losing that amount.........

label: Politics & Government
sentence:
Question: How many anti-fed papers are there? and what was there point of them?
Answer: The Anti-Federalist papers aren't really papers but are a collection of circulars, speeches and pamphlets mostly written by Madison, John Jay, and Alexander Hamilton (most under pen names). They were written in oposition to ratification of the Consitution on the grounds that the document did not protect individual rights sufficiently and provided for a central government that would become too powerful. The Bill of Rights was adopted to address the majority of these concerns. The were finally collected and assembled into 85 sections (to correspond directly with the 85 sections of Federalist Papers by Mr. Morton Borden). The time frame for these circulars/pamphlets was 1787-9.

Question: what is wrong with my yahoo email?
Answer: Try to be a little more specific as to what kind of problem you're having, so that someone here can attempt to help you. Just telling us "what is wrong with my yahoo email?" is too vague.

In Response to "Additional Details Jan 5, 2006 at 5:13 pm" --

Yahoo Mail is VERY quirky and at times unreliable - no doubt about that - but after reading your update, I'm not so sure that Yahoo Mail is entirely at fault here.

From the description of your problem, I think it has something to do with your ISP (internet service provider) BellSouth. If you're on a cable connection, or even dialup, you may be having problems with your ISP successfully delivering your e-mail. You may want to e-mail or call your ISP and tell them about your problem. You could have inadvertently changed some of the settings in your mail account, BellSouth could be having problems with Yahoo Mail compatibility, or they've changed certain protocols for their servers without notifying their customers, which I experienced with my ISP. 

Hope this is helpful.

Answer: Sure, I remember sniglets. They were done by Rich Hall, who was a regular on HBO's Not (Necessarily) the News. I watched that show all the time and sniglets were my favorite part. Some sniglets I remember are:
funch: the act of turning over the pillow, looking for the cool side
hydralation: the act of gradually wetting more parts of your body as you get into a swimming pool
sniffleridge: the ridge running between your nose and your lips

Man, I haven't thought about sniglets in years! Thanks for the memories...

Oh, I remembered one more! Hozone: the mysterious place where socks that disappear from the laundry go.

label: Health
sentence:
Question: how can u cure pain of arthritis?
Answer: If you haven't had a clinical diagnosis, don't give up on the possibility that your pain might not be arthritis. My husband had a variety of symptoms, one of which was joint and bone pain. The doctors tested him for rhumatoid, but the results came back negative. It turned out that he had celiac disease. Celiac primarily impacts the digestive system, but advanced cases of the disease get all sorts of autoimmune problems and nutrient deficiencies - one of which is bone and joint pain. Once he quit getting gluten in his diet his pain completely went away. 

If he gets a gluten infraction the pain will return. We had that last summer when they had cookouts at work pretty regularly for several weeks in a row. He was careful to select foods that were gluten free, but he kept getting a reaction each time. Since he could find no initial cause, he figured he just had a mild viral infection. By the end of two weeks he had terrible bone and joint pain. We finally discovered that Kingsford charcoal uses gluten as a binding agent in their bricketts. The cookouts were with Kingsford. Kingsford stated that the gluten would burn up completely and couldn't contaminate the food; however, my husband's body showed them to be wrong. He quite eating the grilled foods and his symptoms subsided in just a few days. We have come arcross several other celiacs since then who said they had the same problem with Kingsford.

So, if your doctor hasn't difinitively gotten test results that prove arthritis, do a bit of research to see what conditions have this pain as a symptom.

Good luck.

label: Sports
sentence:
Title: how can i get better at the 400 dash?
Question: how can i prepare for the 400 meter dash? i want to get 60 secs.?
i want to run it in 60 seconds flat. any techniques? work outs?

PLEASE DON'T SAY KEEP RUNNING. I NEED EXCERCISES, ENDURANCE, QUOTES. etc.
Answer: Here is some advice I previously posted to another 400m runner.

If you aren't already running 600m in your workout, add them once a week. They build up your strength and help you maintain your speed over that last 100m.  Not knowing your ability, I would say try to run them going out the first 400 at a pace 5-10 seconds slower than your best 400m and then concentrate on staying strong to the finish.

I would also to workouts with multiple 400s, 5-10 seconds slower than your best 400 time, or multiple 200s, a second or two faster than your 400m pace.

You might also try running shorter intevals up a long hill. Back in the 60's, the UCLA team used to run 400s up a long hill. They had the best 4x400 team in the country back then, so the there is evidence that the workouts did some good. 

You need to learn how to run the race correctly. I break the race down into 4 100s. For most of the first 100, you should be accelerating smoothly to your "cruising pace", running hard, but not sprinting all out. The 2nd and 3rd 100s, should be fast, but relaxed. The last 100 is where your strength will have to kick in. You are going to start to feel like someone dropped a weight on your back. We used to say "The bear got him" when we'd watch it happen to a runner in a big way.
 
You'll need to focus on keeping you knees going straight forward. They will want to go off at an angle.  Keep your arms swinging straight ahead. Some runners feel it helps them to exagerate their armswing as it helps keep their legs going.  

Relax your face and jaw. Don't grimace. When you do, it thightens up first your face, then your neck and shoulders.

After a hard run, do a lot of stretching. You've got to have a full range of motion to have a smooth, effortless stride.

I always recommend Bob Anderson's stretching book, it's a classic: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0936070226/002-4340010-1751209\

label: Education & Reference
sentence:
Question: Do penguins have fur or feathers, fins or wings?
Answer: Penguins are birds (Aves) in that they have feathers, lay eggs and have forelimbs modified as wings (but in this case used for swimming). They also share all the other characteristics of birds, being warm-blooded (around 40 deg C) and having a reduced reproductive system (one functional ovary or testis).\nLike all other birds, penguins have feathers. Penguin feathers are short, overlapping and densely packed. The outer part of the feather is waterproof while the inner down section traps an insulating layer of air, keeping the penguin warm in the sometimes freezing water. Unlike those of flying birds, the feathers on a penguin wing are very short.

Although often still discussed in contemporary American politics as representing the quintessential "fringe" end of the far-right spectrum, today the group only exists in the form of a number of very isolated, scattered "supporters" that probably do not number more than a few thousand. In a 2002 report on "Extremism in America", the Anti-Defamation League wrote "Today, there is no such thing as the Ku Klux Klan. Fragmentation, decentralization and decline have continued unabated." However, they also noted that the "need for justification runs deep in the disaffected and is unlikely to disappear, regardless of how low the Klan's fortunes eventually sink."

Today the only known former member of the Klan to hold a Federal office in the United States is Senator Robert Byrd, who says he "deeply regrets" joining the Klan over half a century ago, when he was about 24 years old. There are currently no known members of the Klan who also hold a Federal office.

Some of the larger KKK organizations currently in operation include:

•Church of the American Knights of the Ku Klux Klan 

•Imperial Klans of America 

•Knights of the White Kamelia 

There is a vast number of smaller organizations. As of 2005, there were an estimated 3,000 Klan members, divided among 158 chapters of a variety of splinter organizations, about two-thirds of which were in former Confederate states. The other third are primarily in the Midwest region. 

The ACLU has provided legal support to various factions of the KKK in defense of their First Amendment rights to hold public rallies, parades, and marches, and their right to field political candidates.

In a July 2005 incident, a Hispanic man's house was burned down in Hamilton, Ohio, after accusations that he sexually assaulted a nine-year-old white girl. Klan members in Klan robes showed up afterward to distribute pamphlets.

Sensitivity to the highly-charged topic of the KKK is in evidence at professional baseball games. Fans will sometimes post a letter "K" (the scoring symbol for strikeout) every time the home team pitcher strikes out a batter. Typically the letters will be spaced in such a way that no three consecutive K's are run together. Another approach is to have every third one be a backwards K, although a reversed K more typically denotes a strikeout in which the batter does not swing at the third strike.
